q: What is the main idea of Application of Integrals?
a: Application of integrals involves using definite integrals to calculate quantities like area under curves, area between curves, and other physical quantities.

q: Formula for area under a curve y=f(x) from x=a to x=b?
a: Area = \( \int_a^b f(x) dx \), where f(x) ≥ 0 in [a,b].

q: What if f(x) takes negative values in [a,b]?
a: Area = \( \int_a^b |f(x)| dx \). Split the interval where f(x) changes sign.

q: Area between two curves y=f(x) and y=g(x) from x=a to x=b?
a: Area = \( \int_a^b [f(x) - g(x)] dx \), where f(x) ≥ g(x) in [a,b].

q: How to find area when curves intersect?
a:
1. Find intersection points x=a and x=b.
2. Split integral if necessary where top and bottom curves change.
3. Use \( \int [top-bottom] dx \) for each interval.

q: Area between curves x=f(y) and x=g(y) from y=c to y=d?
a: Area = \( \int_c^d [f(y) - g(y)] dy \), where f(y) ≥ g(y) in [c,d].

q: Tip: changing order of integration for horizontal slices
a: Sometimes it's easier to integrate w.r.t y (horizontal slices) instead of x (vertical slices). Use x=f(y) formulas.

q: Area enclosed by curves y=f(x), y=g(x), x=a, x=b
a: Use \( \int_a^b [f(x) - g(x)] dx \). Make sure to check which curve is on top in each interval.

q: Area bounded by curve and x-axis (general tip)
a: If curve crosses x-axis, split at zeros of f(x) and take absolute value of each part: \( \int |f(x)| dx \).

1. If f(x) is even: \( \int_{-a}^a f(x) dx = 2 \int_0^a f(x) dx \)
2. If f(x) is odd: \( \int_{-a}^a f(x) dx = 0 \).
\( \int_0^a f(x) dx = \int_0^a f(a-x) dx \). Useful for simplifying integrals.

q: Area between two curves example tip
a: Check if curves intersect within limits. If yes, split integral at intersection points to find accurate area.

q: Special case: region enclosed by y=f(x) and x-axis only
a: Area = \( \int_{x_1}^{x_2} |f(x)| dx \), where x_1 and x_2 are zeros of f(x).

q: Special case: region enclosed by x=f(y) and y-axis only
a: Area = \( \int_{y_1}^{y_2} |f(y)| dy \), where y_1 and y_2 are zeros of f(y).
Always sketch the curves first to identify top/bottom or right/left functions before integrating.
Check signs of functions in intervals, split if necessary, and always take absolute values where required to get actual area.
For simple curves and standard functions, formulas for definite integrals of polynomials, trigonometric and exponential functions can be directly used.
